38911699.review:
[i]Review applies to version 1.1.51[/i]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b][u]Early Access[/u][/b] - The game can change before it is 'released'
[b][u]Controls[/u][/b] - Default controls are a little akward
[b][u]Lack of instructions[/u][/b] - some aspects of the game lack any form of instructions on their purpose or usage. (Chalk it up to Early Access for now.)
[b][u]Difficulty[/u][/b] - Elvish = easy mode. Come on we aren't THAT wimpy! (Yes, this one is a joke...)
[b][u]UI is raw[/u][/b] - A result of being in easy access, I hope, the UI in some areas could use improvement.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b][u]Quaint Artstyle[/u][/b] - Uses a style of pixel art that does not use outlines and does it well. (Opinion based, sorry.)
[b][u]Controls Can Be Adjusted[/u][/b] - While the default is a bit akward you are able to switch the keybindings to be more comfortable.
[b][u]Ease of learning[/u][/b] - The game is pretty easy to learn and you get into the [i]swing[/i] of things pretty quickly.

[h1]Explanation and Details[/h1]
First, I will explain that I am bias on two fronts. I am not a fan of dwarves (sorry, I am an elf at heart) and I adore pixel art games thanks to growing up with games such as Monkey Island. Despite my bias on dwarves I found this game to be (in it's current Early Access state) quite enjoyable in it's raw function and form. That is to say the premise of the game has promise.

The controls are a little akward in their default stage, but can be altered to fit your personal comfort. The User Interface is refined in some areas and lacking in others. (White on light colors can be hard to read.) The game play itself is fairly simple and strait forward. Even so it leaves room for a sense of self in terms of what you build/upgrade and when. There is no linear path (that I could tell) that you are forced to travel and you are free to explore at your own pace.

It turned out to be a fairly relaxing game.  Even with the intense moments of combat.

Charming game. Even in early Access the game is fully playable, at least i haven't reached the end game yet. (4 hours gameplay)

Cons
- Combat could be more refined...sorry i really wish i could be more specific, sometimes seems like it's lagging ( there's a slow mo to help you recover after you get hit, but...) The enemy have a tendency to zerg you and if you kite then you kill 90%. 
- Some decisions, let me explain: There's a tavern, you can play a "game in this place... it's a completely time waster mouse clicking game, why is it a con? because you actually upgadre important stuff in your camp if you play it so get ready to spend a lot of time clicking (or download a fast clicker)
- tutorial and some keybinds. This one is minor, the game is not that complicated and you can rebind your controls.

Pro
- Great idea, there is exploration and sense of discovery

- Upgrading your character and camp feels very satisfying

- Combat (i know, pro and con at the same time), reflect a fireball was just epic! the stealth mechanic is not half bad.

- Not only a great concept the execution is going very well. Just a fun game.

Keep up devs, and i look to see this game finished and future ones.

38662201.review:
Have you ever played an Elder Scrolls game and wished you could play a dwarf? Swinging an axe around, drinking your weight in ale and plundering caverns for the treasures of your ancestors and maybe sacking the hidden banks of some dirty elves? Well stop. You won't ever be able to play a dwarf in Elder Scrolls.

Instead, hop into Regions of Ruin and become the most badass pixel dwarf ever. Unite your people against displacement caused by ravaging orcs, goblins and other freaky and goulish fiends. Build a community and slowly retake back both the underground and the sun backed soil your people were driven from. 

If you ever played games like Kingdom: Classic or New Lands, or side scrolling adventure RPGs or maybe you want to try something differrent, pick this game. It is incredible and worth every penny.

Pros:
* You're a dwarf with a badass beard.
* Skill Tree (providing many ways to build your dwarf and play the game)
* Extensive Loot system
* Easy to use inventory
* Forge (you can dismanle items for resources or create your own)
* Great resource management + options of obtainment (send out workers while you adventure)
* Village building (build and upgrade your community with resources + expand populace by rescueing and recruiting dwarves)
* Open world map exploration (uses a map based on resources)
* RPG with main story and lore (with references to Dwarf Fortress!)
* Impressive soundtrack/SE and pixel art (with a night and day system)
* Frequent updates and content patches!
* Devs love this project (and so it won't be neglected)

Cons:
* Platforming can be a bit tricky to ascend elevations of any kind, especially if enemies are mounted above you.
* Throwing is a bit janky but not impossible/hard.
* No "sprinting". You can use a Dash but that's more of a quick jump forward. 
* Resources become hard to gather the further you go as they become very scarce.
* You can't customize your dwarf body. I want a red beard damn it. xD
* You get an itching for more when you need sleep.

I cannot imagine what this game will become out of early access and all of the content and features it might add since I'm already really impressed with it.  However, I am excited for the future! Great work devs, you made a wonderfull game!

5/5

38578026.review:
Every once in a while, a game, and development team, comes along out of the blue with a wonderful little gem.  Regions of Ruin is one of those games.

While very simple on the surface, it delivers.  If you're a casual hack 'n slasher, or a stat crunching min/maxer, this game will scratch either itch, and leave you thinking about it after you've moved on with your day.  

The pixel art, though simple, is really charming and, "fits," the world they've created.  Rebindable keys for mouse and keyboard (haven't tried it with a controller, so I can't comment on that) is also another boon.  

As for the team... amazing.  Just amazing.  Don't believe me?  Jump on their Discord channel and say hello.  Very responsive, very helpful, and really, really friendly.  

Though it is in early access, and I think we've all seen a good game fail or become abandoned, I don't have such a fear from this title.  Weekly updates combined with the development team's engagement with the community tells me this is a title that's going to make it to the finish line.

The short of it is this:  If you're on the fence with this one, go ahead and take that leap--It's a fun title with plenty of room to grow.

37736547.review:
Regions of Ruin is a platformer-rpg-townbuilder mix with an engaging (and growing) amount of backstory in the form of a vibrant atmosphere and plenty of lore. It features an easy to use but difficult to master combat system with a nice little skilltree for players to customize their play style, and an interesting armor and damage system including some very "entertaining" injuries the player can sustain ("Deformed Buttocks" cough cough).
Being a fan of games like Kingdom, this is right up my alley, as it expands on the aforementioned titles limited gameplay and even offers an "open" world for the player to explore at their leisure.
----
Despite being in early access I have yet to encounter any major bugs (smaller bugs I have thusfar encountered have already been patched, all within a few weeks). New content usually arrives at a weekly pace, including new locations to explore, additional enemies to slay and interesting items to slay with / help with the slaying. The devs are very active, supportive of their fans and open to suggestions, something which is sadly lacking in many modern games and developers.
I have high hopes for this game's future, and wish the devs the best of luck for their future endeavors.
----
My current playtime reflects the amount of time it took me to completely finish the game in it's current state; so expect to get around 30+ hours depending on your playstyle.

Great fun so far!

Reminds me of the old "King Arthur's World" SNES game but you play the main character.

Pros:
- Multiple character builds & playstyles available
- Good pacing keeps game moving forward
- Good balance between managing resources, inventory, stats, and combat action.
- Great Dwarf Fortress side references! :)
- More content on the way!

Minor complaints:
- A little wonkey platforming (e.g. landing on the edge of a platform & dashing to get out)

- Somewhat tedious to pick up all the items after clearing a board

- Somewhat tedious shopping (not clear which items are best, limited cash supply in each shop)

Wish List:
- Stamina would be unlimited in home camp and after clearing a stage (so could dash more and move faster)
- Could sort items in shop by price / magic value / base material etc...

Overall good game, good value, and looking forward to finishing this content and seeing what more is in store!

Cheers!

36519598.review:
Regions Of Ruin est tout simplement génial ! Les développeurs ont étendu un concept simpliste et efficace ressemblant furieusement à "Kingdom" mais lui ont ajouté énormément de dimensions supplémentaires !
Tout comme dans Kindom vous vous déplacez dans un monde en 2D, mais ce monde en 2D se révèle être agrémenté d'un autre monde en 2D... La carte... Au final on se retrouve avec un monde qui finalement démultiplie les dimensions et offre une expérience de jeu extrêmement intéressante ! Je n'irai  pas j'usqua la 4D même si théoriquement et mathématiquement c'est vers ce genre de dimension que le calcul nous emmène, mais la profondeur est quoi qu'il en soit indéniable !
Ajoutez à tous cela un aspect RP certe basique (Pas de Dungeon & Dragon ici) cela à le mérite d'ajouter encore quelques éléments supplémentaires à la superbe de ce jeu !
Les graphismes sont très joli, le moteur graphique est bien optimisé car même sur mon mini PC portable avec juste un APU AMD bas de gamme il tourne à merveille !
En résumé ce jeu possède une réelle profondeur, un gameplay intéressant alliant RPG, exploration, action, stratégie et gestion bref que du bon ! Bravo aux concepteur car la formule marche à merveille !

36502216.review: I've been playing this game a while now, very addicting combination of RPG and brawler. Combat requires a little bit of strategy, which is great, and the game is extremely difficult early on but it pays off. I enjoyed the town building and resource gathering elements, however it becomes clear pretty quickly which resources you end up using the most and some times those can be hard to get a hold of, especially in the case of the food resource which is scarce and gets used up quickly trying to uncover parts of the map. it is a little frustrating to use the food resource to uncover new levels only to find the levels hadn't been added into the game yet, although since it's under development I'm mostly grumpy about having to wait. Overall I'd say the game is a lot of fun and easy to get sucked into, but resource management needs a bit of work and difficulty levels fluctuate very heavily between levels, some are much too easy and some take multiple retries. Currently puzzle elements seem incomplete and the map is a little confusing. Can't wait until the game is completed though. Even with all the things that need improving the game is a blast.

This game is so addicting.
Imagine the gameplay style similar to the game known as Kingdoms without the hastle.

You are a dwarf trying to build up his city to get stronger and stronger.
Like most RPGs there are XP progression and gear progression. 
When you level up your can add a stat point and use a skill point which can only be done at a firepit.

As for exploring the mechanic involves getting food from towns/areas then using that food to unlock parts of the map (Based on distance away from the city you are building). The further the town the more it costs (kind of obvious). Once you unlock that part of the map it is free to travel to the nodes at any time. (HIgher campfires mean your search area gets bigger so it becomes more efficient to use food).

As for the fighting. So far i've only played a melee character where i am using a shield and a melee weapon. Cutting down enemies left and center. Though the games difficulty increases dramatically as the more damage you take the less you can sustain. If you take no major injury (text on screen) it means you can regenerate your health to perfect health.
Meaning Magic attacks even though brutal damage it doesn't cause permanent damage.

Bosses are just named enemies with a higher health pool, hits harder and has a few unique tactics.

As for building up your town. After you explore for abit you'll see dwarves trapped in cages (Only release them after you've dispatched all the enemies) these can be used to automatically gather resources from completed zones. Each dwarf is 1 resource per 5 seconds. Until that resource pool has been used up. 

Not going to say more about the game as I'd like you to experience the game yourself. I'd recommend this game for it's game mechanics even though the combat is kind clunky to get your head around at the start.

35814255.review: Preview (Early Release) This newest game in this sug-category of sidescrolling rpg/strategy games is shaping up to be something out of the ordinary - even this early in development it's becoming clear that this is a passion project and I have seldom (if ever) enjoyed an early release this much. The game is a well balanced mix of exploration, rpg, strategy, citybuilding and crafting. This game however doesn't fall into the trap of oversimplifying combat - which while seeming deceptively simple actually has a fair amount strategy and complexities below the simplistic surface and  well demand more of you than you would imagine from a game of this type - but don't be fooled on higher difficulties it has enough challenge to make you rage. It is a ton of fun to build/improve your colony through adventures, rescues and crafting and while many of the features are still being implemented/completed  its easy to see where the game is going and I suspect i'll end up doing  a lot of complete playthroughs - this is the kind of game you can enjoy over and over. This has easily been my favorite early release in 2017 - Hell I'd go as far as saying this game is my personal favorite of 2017. The game grabs you and before you know it hours has passed and sure they have a ways to go before this game is done but these devs are as welcoming and appreciative of feedback as any I have ever seen. I wholeheartedly recommend you join their discord if you have ANY questions and/or feedback. If you have enjoyed games like Kingdoms, Era, Starbound etc - then you will easily fall in love this game. This is definitely a game and developer worth supporting and were I to rate it I'd have to give them a 9.5 / 10.

35780812.review:
Look, I dont usually go for this pixel crap, but like the golden rule always proves:
Gameplay>Graphics.
And there is no better example of that than in Regions of Ruin. A pixely little game in which you must go around the lands running amok, grabbing resources wherever you can, saving your peon gatherers and eventually, rebuilding your lost above-ground(???) dwarven kingdom.
Along your travels you will encounter many quest givers, collectibles, puzzles to unlock and chained events.
As you build up your town you can take advantages of the perks from each building (taverns give companions for hire, apothecary lets you craft medkits; blacksmith lets you tear down and recreate better weapons, refinery allows you to smelt ores for better ingots, better craftings, and a library allows for saving your recovered pages to books.
You may be thinking that's a lot. And for a pixel game, it is. Which is why I felt the needed to review this ambitious little gem.

35690232.review:
[h1]Regions of Ruin - это пиксельная РПГ про дварфов, за которую в раннем доступе просят 649 рублей и которая, неожиданно, стоит каждой копейки уже сейчас. You don't wanna miss it. [/h1]

[b]Regions of Ruin[/b] – это одна из самых отполированных и играбильных игр в раннем доступе, что я видел. За 6 часов в игре я не встретил ни одного бага и единственные плэйсхолдеры, которые мне попались – это слоты в интерфейсе библиотеки и ограниченная прокачка зданий. В остальном уже сейчас перед нами полноценная игра, готовая, скорей всего, где-то на треть, но эта треть играется и ощущается абсолютно целостно, а не как сырой продукт из раннего доступа. 

Открытый и интересный мир, куча лута, включая редкий, крафт, прокачка, разнообразные квесты, боевка с челленджем — все это и даже больше уже сейчас есть в Regions of Ruin. А судя по всему, в игре также будет режим рогалика, потому что описание к сложности «Dwarf», которая пока недоступна, гласит, что у нас будет одна жизнь и сэйв удаляется автоматически после смерти. 

Я положительно не могу найти в этой игре каких-то явных недостатков. Да, некоторые аспекты простоваты, но это абсолютно не портит игровой процесс, а иногда даже делает его лучше и проще. Именно поэтому порог вхождения в игру очень низок – вы не будете биться головой об стену и учиться играть часами даже на самом высоком уровне сложности. 

[h1]В Regions of Ruin все работает, и вы понимаете, как и почему оно работает именно так. Эту игру ждет большой успех и толпы фанатов – mark my words.[/h1]

Полный обзор: http://blast-games.ru/obzori/regions-of-ruin-obzor

Leveling system, equipment upgrades, and all the RPG elements you come to love? Check.

35533874.review:
First, I need to be clear that this is a review on day 2 of early access.  The game is not finished.  There are many places you cannot go and get a message that the area isn't in yet.  Items and abilities have numbers attached to them, but none of those numbers have actually been balanced yet.

That being said, core mechanics are in place and feel well thought out.  Given only the broad outlines of a goal to gather dwarves together to stand against the goblin king, it feels fun to explore locations to see what I'll find.  As you explore locations, you rescue dwarves that will help you gather resources to grow your town.  The little mini quests in areas I explore are varied enough that exploration is its own reward; I don't feel like I'm just clearing identical areas in some sort of resource grind.

What makes the casual exploration gameplay really work is the art syle.  How you feel about this game is going to depend largely on how you feel about pixel art.  Personally, I am amazed how expressive the low pixel count characters are.  It takes a particular talent to create features by altering the color of individual pixels.  My favorite is the dwarf who is clearly dressed as a plague doctor.

35504091.review:
This is an extremely early review into their Early Access stage. In the future I will probably change my review.
I have extremely high hopes for this game! It's fun and quick, but not without fault. I'll split this into positives and negatives.

Pros:
+ Extremely easy to pick up
+ Pretty neat aesthetic
+ Most if not all of the promised features in the game already work (I feel like this is important to note with Early Access titles in 2017)
+ Devs are definitely devoted
+ Love the health system. There's something great there! It's not a simple health bar, but instead an immersive and in-depth overview of how screwed you are. Not enough RPGs take that into consideration!
+ Every dwarf has personality!

Cons:
- Changing controls doesn't seem to work. I've tried three times to change my controls and have been unable to.
- The attacking/counterattacking system doesn't feel very satisfying, as combat usually is 1v3-1v6, not allowing for any sort of attack other than spam left clicks and kite. Throwing is extremely useful in this regard, though.
- The sound is all over the place from quiet to explosively loud
- Compared to Kingdom too much, the game is way different than Kingdom. I totally see where the comparison is from the aesthetic, but gameplay-wise it's very unique.
- Pacing is very poor as of right now, you can play 30 minutes and already have a great deal of buildings built. As a result, it doesn't feel very rewarding to build the next one.
- The resolution of the game itself feels too low, and could be a little zoomed out.
- Any problem your character has from battle is instantly cured by a little apothecary dwarf for a few coins. It kinda removes the intensity of the health system they have in place

The cons will probably will be worked out with a little polish. I don't often say that, but I get a good vibe from these guys. All in all, this game is shaping up quickly. At the rate they're going, it looks like by it's release it'll be an extremely solid game, and a steal at the asking price!

35496992.review:
tldr: a fun unique game that brings back memories of Kingdom combined with a skill based open world RPG. Enough available content alrady in the Early Access version, lots of unique areas to visit, enemies to fight, quests to do, loot and resources to collect in order to gear up fight bosses, level up and unlock more skills to complete quests and build your dwarven kingdom.

If Kingdom and Elder Scrolls had a baby, that would be called Regions of Ruin. RoR is hevily inspired by Kingdom but it's a completely different game at the same time, it's a side-scrolling RPG where you explore, fight, level up, and build your town. The world has a ton of unique areas, quests, loot and resources waiting for you. You will die a lot or you can change the difficulty if you are not into fighting signigicantly better than you enemies, you can visit and complete each area in the order you chose and you can recruit mercenaries to assist you in combat and workers to farm resources for you.

The combat is trickier the higher the difficulty you chose, you can dash to avoid enemies, or sneak to sneak attack them, you have a power hit and the ability to throw axes in your enemies face. When you level up, you unlock abilities that will make your job easier. The skill tree has 4 categories: melee attacks, ranged attacks, shield and power hits and you can chose the path that fits to your playstyle. There is a good variety in the enemies already in the Early Access version and bosses that you can find the more you explore the map in the further away areas.

You "build" your town by spending resources for buildings that automaticaly get build there for you. Some of them offer you different things for example a tavern to hire recruits to assist you in combat, or a forge to make your own equipment and an apothecary to make bandages. There are 8 buildings currently available that can also be upgrated to provide more perks.

There is an open world, you visit new in the order you want and all of them are handcrafted not procedurally generated. That means that everything is placed there for a reason. There isn't an infinite world but it has almost 60 areas already in the Early Access version for you to explore. The areas can be forests, deserts, caves, farms, ruins, strongholds but each one of them is different from the previous ones. You always have new stuff to do and find.
 
There is a good variety of npcs (50+?), most of them with unique dialoque. Some of them offer you quests to help them in one way or an other, some of them come and stay in your settlement to be used (medic, blacksmith, vendors etc) and some others you can used as workers to farm resources for you.

The lore is a mystery you have to figure out by talking to people and collecting some book pages. Currently not finished in the EA version but there are some good amount of text already written. You can also notice a subtle sense of humor in some area's signs or in the gameplay itself, for example your injuries names or that you can apply your skill points by pressing P (peeing) in the campfire etc.

The art style you either love or hate, it's a decent pixelart with some nice scenery and lots and lots of different hand drawn areas, buildings, enemies, npcs, items and biomes.

The music is fantastic, gotta love it when a game has a good soundtrack that fits the games universe and hypes you. 

Controls offer you a variety of options, i use keyboard but as far as i know the controllers will be fully supported too. I tested it in windows but also as far as i know the game runs smoothly on Linux and Mac too. Performace is great in my 5+ year old laptop with an i5@1.80ghz and a gtx970m, it will probably run smoothly in any pc.

The game still needs a lot of work to extend the content, new areas to visit, new quests and maybe more weapons, armor types and buildings for your settlement and of course the lore, the ending and everything story-related but i'm sure everything will be there in the full version.

The developer is a solo-dev, very passionate about this game since the day i met him he is fixing bugs left and right and adds new content in regular basis. The current version of the game offers you at least 12-15 hours of play time that can be easily reach the 20 depending on your playstyle and difficulty (edit: apparently some people after the EA launch are finishing it in 5-10 hours so it's totaly up to you how much it will take to you for now). They plan to make the content triple during the early access, the map is huge and only 1/3-1/4 of it is available currently so i expect it will need 40-60 hours to complete it after EA. The game is fun, unique and if it seems interesting/promising for you i would highly recommend it to you to check it out and give it a chanse.

I hope this review was useful to you as i tried to cover as many things as possible. I was one of the testers of the game and had a blast testing it so far. I didn't pay for my copy of the game that's why the review is marked as "copy given for free" and as "other type of purchase, tester copy".

39242898.review:
[h1][b][u]You are a short, sturdy creature fond of drink and industry[/u][/b][/h1] 

Regions of Ruin is a delightful, addictive, action-adventure, platforming, settlement building, exploration and discovery game. The pixel art is beautiful. The enemy engagements can feel deliberate and methodical, or chaotic, depending on your chosen tactics. It’s early access, but already seriously fun, and the devs churn out updates like madmen.

[b][u]What I love:[/u][/b]
- The world is fantastic. Discovering the secrets of your ancestor’s ruined homes is especially delightful. They really nailed the wonder of discovery and exploration. The story is felt and experienced, not forced.
- Seeing your town come to life as you make progress is extremely satisfying
- The pixel art is beautiful. From the adorable kobold dwellings, to the malevolent, grimacing lightning wizards, this game oozes charm.
- Companions can be quite helpful when you don’t need to be sneaky. It can be really fun to bring two or three companions and face a whole fort full of goblins or orcs head on.
- The skill trees are pretty well done as far as I can tell. If you choose wisely you really feel the increase in power as you improve certain skills.
- When stealth is not employed, battles become appropriately chaotic. I could see some people getting frustrated with being overwhelmed by enemies, but that’s often a sign that you need to take a different approach, i.e. sneak, hire companions, return when you’re stronger etc.

[b][u]What would be nice to see:[/u][/b]
- Flesh the world out even more. The devs are clearly working hard on this, but the more full and alive the world feels the better. More rumors. More stories. More secrets.
- Perhaps add more flavor to the companions. Maybe some unique ones could be found/rescued. Also, if companions become more permanent, perhaps you could opt to leave them at your base if you want to go it alone for a bit.
- It might be fun if some areas were larger. Sneaking about in a huge orc fortress would be pretty epic.
- Magic, possibly. If it doesn’t thematically fit for the player to get to use magic then that’s okay. Some of the enemies have really cool magic abilities though. It would be fun to get use them (If it wouldn’t completely unbalance the game. Balance is more important)
- Town events could be cool. Maybe dwarves could come to town from a region you liberated to ask you to go back there and deal with a problem. Maybe your town could be attacked. On that note, maybe you could build town defenses to deter raids. Maybe you could hire/train/equip militia to defend your town. Maybe if you cause trouble for powerful enemies before your defenses are strong, you get sacked hard.

[b][u]What needs to be fixed:[/u][/b]
- Sometimes the quest-giver dudes get killed in battle, and the quest remains with no way to finish it. I’d say either make the quest-giver invulnerable, like the caravan guy, or make the quest disappear if they die.
- Oftentimes I’ll complete the objective of a quest, but have no idea where I have to go to finish it. The journal entry only includes the quest objective, not the quest origin.
- No clue what to do with the runeforge. I’ve dissolved a bunch of stuff, but I don’t see an “imbue” option for any of my items.
- There seems to be a bit of imbalance in resources. In my current game, I’ve been through dozens of areas since I found one where I can harvest hides. Nearly every forest seems to yield only lumber.

Keep up the good work devs!

40756793.review:
Maybe I've become spoiled. There was probably a time when I was younger where I would've liked this game as-is. All the mechanics are functional enough, the graphics work, and the idea? It's a frickin' side-scrolling Castlevania-exploration Dwarf Fortress! What could possibly go wrong?

The tragic answer is that the game is completely soulless, and I couldn't get through a single hour of it.

1. The plot is given to you immediately upon the start of your game through a massive text-dump giving setting, backstory, and purpose, telling you everything about what you're going to be doing and exploring before you even start and thus killing any chance of interesting new discovery on the spot.
2. The NPCs are the most generically-written blobs I've ever seen. "I am a healer! Come to me if you've been wounded and I'll heal you for a price!" "I'm a farmer! Get these kobolds off my lands and I'll join your cause!" It's all dry and utilitarian. You're not making a colony of dwarves- you're making a colony of robots.
3. You sustain wounds via the same sort of anatomical injury deal that games like DF give you, but the wound types, you quickly learn, are basically meaningless. If it's a puncture to the neck or a sprain to the foot, it's just straight HP damage regardless, and there is no difference between the injuries or their effect on your fighting.
4. Alright, because I never got through the first hour of it, I'll admit that this criticism probably isn't explored enough to be valid, but after killing several camps of mute, personality-void goblins and then experiencing several camps of almost identically mute, personality-void kobolds, I was done. Aside from their appearances and the poison damage kobolds used, the two were practically interchangable, and the thought of fighting emotionless drones like these for hours turned me off this game completely.

I'm sorry to give a game with this much work in it a negative review, because I think the spritework is legitimately praiseworthy, but the first impressions this game leave a lot to be desired. I could probably forgive the generic-sounding music and the overbearing tutorial otherwise.

40692514.review:
[h1]Skyrim w pikselach[/h1]

[b]W skrócie:[/b] W tej grze będziesz wieść życie krasnoluda i będzie to dobre życie. Zaczniesz od zabijania goblinów i założenia osady, a po 10 minutach zorientujesz się, że grałeś całą noc i stworzyłeś krasnoludzkie imperium, a wraz ze swoją wierną świtą doborowych wojów wyprawiasz się w najbardziej niebezpieczne rejony świata, odkrywając coraz to nowe tajemnice i zdobywając niewyobrażalne skarby. Uważaj, [i]Regions of Ruin[/i] to Arcyklejnot Thráina wśród indie RPGów.

[b]Po długości:[/b] [i]Regions of Ruin[/i] nie jest piękne, nie ma idealnego sterowania, czasem coś nie sztymuje w kodzie, czasem będzie za łatwe, czasem za trudne, a czasem za nudne, ale i tak nie oderwiesz się od tej gry, póki jej nie skończysz. A teraz o kilku konkretnych kwestiach, na które warto zwrócić uwagę:

[olist]
[*]Opowieść
Gdyby kogoś to ciekawiło, to fabuła w [i]Regions of Ruin[/i] jest prosta jak budowa cepa – śledzimy wędrówkę naszego dzielnego, niskiego bohatera od zera do przywódcy krasnoludzkiego królestwa. Nic Was tu nie zaskoczy, typical Skyrim level.

[*]Język
W grze jest mnóstwo tekstu, a copywriter nie miał prostego zadania, gdyż wszystkie wypowiedzi należało zmieścić w niewielkich, komiksowych dymkach. Szczęśliwie zabrał się za to ktoś z głową na karku – wypowiedzi postaci są naturalne i nieprzerysowane. NPC wypowiadają swoje kwestie prostym językiem, czasem stylizowanym na szkoc… krasnoludzki, ale to nie jest reguła. Mówiąc krótko – teksty trzymają poziom i nie wybijają z imersji, a ilość literówek jest śladowa. Przyznaję order językoznawcy.

[*]UI i sterowanie
Tu nie jest źle, ale mogłoby być lepiej. Sterowanie z początku wydaje się nieintuicyjne, ale szybko można się przyzwyczaić. Inna bajka to interface, który na początku wydaje się bardzo przejrzysty i prosty w obsłudze, ale w miarę jak gra się rozwija, nasz bohater rośnie w siłę i przybywa mikrozarządzania osadą, zaczyna brakować kilku opcji, takich jak np. przydzielenie 5 lub 10 pracowników do jednej lokacji, masowego przydzielenia pracowników do różnych stref wydobycia, usunięcia wszystkich krasnoludów z pustych kopalnii, albo zwykłego szybkiego zestawienia obok siebie statystyk dwóch przedmiotów. Drobnostki, ale znacznie ułatwiłyby życie. Ogólnie jest dobrze, a te braki nie przeszkadzają cieszyć się grą, choć czasem rodzi się w głowie takie małe BOŻE DLACZEGO.

[*]Level design
Jestem pod wrażeniem. W tak niskiej cenie dostajemy grę, która oferuje nam duży świat i zupełną swobodę eksploracji, a w którym lokacji właściwie się nie powtarzają. Za każdym razem, kiedy klikam na kolejne miejsce oczekuję nowej przygody i prawie nigdy nie jestem zawiedziony tym, co otrzymuję! Poziomy są bardzo krótkie, ale niesamowicie zróżnicowane. Podbijamy najeżone wrogami twierdze, odwiedzamy osady innych krasnoludzkich plemion, walczymy z bestiami w leśnych ostępach, podejmujemy się zadań i zleceń, odkrywamy starożytne ruiny (i rozwiązujemy staroszkolne łamigłówki!), zapuszczamy się w głąb kopalni… A ponadto wiele z odwiedzanych lokacji wykorzystujemy (po oczyszczeniu z potworów), jako źródło surowców naturalnych, co czasem jest w naturalny sposób powiązane z misjami, które tam wykonujemy. Jak mówią twórcy: „no randomized maps or levels, everything you see has been made with care” – i ponieważ to jest prawda, to jest to jedna z najbardziej wyjątkowych gier pośród proceduralnie generowanego kału, jaki nas dzisiaj zalewa.

[*]Balans
Bez owijania w bawełnę – bywa różnie. Dobrze rozwinięte rzucanie toporami pozwala nam wybijać nawet najmocniejsze potwory z bezpiecznego dystansu, choć na szczęście zdarza się, że nasze tomahawki nie przebiją się przez co lepiej opancerzonych przeciwników. W kuźni wykujemy przedmioty zdecydowanie zbyt potężne na nasz poziom, by po kilku godzinach uznać, że są już za słabe, a nie możemy jeszcze wytwarzać lepszych. Możemy przypadkiem trafić do ruin i rozwiązać zagadkę, która odblokuje dla nas endgameową broń (a możemy jej używać, bo nie ma żadnych ograniczeń). Tak, ta gra ma problemy z balansem – mniej więcej takie, jak Skyrim. Przy tej ilości zazębiających się systemów uniknięcie tego jest niemal niemożliwe i właściwie w niczym nie przeszkadza.

[*]Endgame
W recenzjach czasem przewija się stwierdzenie, że gra szybko robi się powtarzalna, a na późniejszych etapach nie oferuje już nic nowego. To prawda, ale problem nie leży w braku contentu, tylko w złym jego skalowaniu. Świetne gameplayowe pomysły szybko rosną do rozmiarów, które stają się zwyczajnie uciążliwe dla gracza i odblokowują się zbyt szybko. A jednak nawet po wyczyszczeniu większej części mapy nadal chciałem odkrywać nowe tereny i szukać kolejnych sekretów. Magia.

[*]Bugi
Jest dobrze. Zdarzają się drobne błędy, jak np. to, że jakaś postać umrze, zanim oddamy jej questa, albo jakiś znacznik nie pojawi się na mapie, ale nie jest to nic, co uniemożliwia grę, ale powoduje, że siadam w kącie i płaczę. Widać, że zakodowano to z głową. Czasem tylko przeszkadzają niechlujne ramki na tekst, które nie dość dobrze dopasowują się do długich wypowiedzi NPCów. Tak, czepiam się.
[/olist]

Podsumowując, jest to jeden z najlepszych małych/indie RPGów ostatnich lat. Może i nie jest idealny, ale nic lepszego nie znajdziecie. [b]Kingdom na sterydach, Skyrim w pikselach.[/b]

Short version: it's great, give it a try.

I really enjoyed this title. It's a very nice looking game with an elegantly simple control scheme and RPG/levelling system. It's a ton of fun to build your city and explore all the (hand-made) levels on the map. It's also easy to get in and out of, given the small size of every single little region and you can save at almost any time. 

There are a few bugs here and there, but nothing for me that killed the game (I had one bug where a quest could not be completed, but I believe the dev is aware of these, and will fix in short order). There are also non game-breaking balance issues that can make things a bit too easier due to loot drops, and materials can feel useless once the town is fully upgraded. This really shouldn't deter anyone however, as it doesn't really affect the fun factor. And if things get too easy, you can always increase the difficulty level at any time.

It took me 20 hours spread over 5 days to finish the game on normal difficulty, and I will most likely have another go with a different build just for the heck of it. 

I heartily recommend this title.

40485041.review:
Great Fun Little Game

Is Regions of Ruins going to change the gaming world? No.
Is Regions of Ruins going to keep you enthralled for hours? Yes!

Like most indie games, Regions of Ruins does little to take you by the hand and guide you through the game basics. 
Unlike most indie games you'll learn quickly and you will like it, because succeeding means being richly rewarded: magic items, coins, resources to be gathered, workers for your settlement... you have every incentive to pay attention, and grasping the basics isn't hard by any mean. 
These rewards will help make your character noticeably stronger. For example the new magic weapon you took from an enemy camp will really make a difference during the next fight, or the new resources unlocked will allow you to improve your apothecary and manufacture healing potions, which can truly make a difference in many fights. 
All is done well and without needless frills. 

Yes, the quests are linear: go there and kill the goblins, come back and pick up your reward. But honestly who cares? You are supposed to play the part of a hard fighting and (presumably) hard drinking dwarf, not of a Venetian diplomat trying to build and destroy alliances in the XVI century. 
Speaking of hard drinking, here's a little tip: your tavern is more than just a place were adventures flock to have a drink and you can recruit them. Far more: it can actually open the way to very powerful upgrades if you look hard enough.
And here's one of the strong points: you are incentivated to look everywhere and explore every location. It may be for mere greed or because you just need more coal to smelt more metal ingots but exploration is always rewarded. 

The game has some negatives. As said it will do little to teach you anything, from settlement development to magic item creation. There are a few broken quests (report them on the discussion board so they can be fixed). But worst of all is how disorganized the journal is and how little it helps with [spoiler] rune combinations [/spoiler].
None of this is a deal breaker and at the present rate most issues will be fixed in the near future.

I really hope the promise at the end for more explorations in the future will be kept because I am having a whole lot of fun right now.

40448721.review:
Its a good game. 

That said it can be very frustrating, not in terms of the A.I (enemies are certainly challenging but I'll get back to that in a moment). The issue with the game is it often does not provide guidance on how certain mechanics work, for instance, how you 'Explore' and then 'Travel' are not really taught, and I had to trawl the internet for a while to find an answer to this issue (F.Y.I you click on the map, not the locations and so long as you have enough food you 'explore' that area and can travel to the locations within). 

As you can expect you are provided a limited storage capacity which you can increase, you'll have a few workers to source finite materials from areas you have cleared. Added to this when you enter certain areas there are ample resources literally lying around that you can collect SO LONG as you can store them at home, so naturally you come across stockpiles you can't just take with you. Irritatingly they VANISH if you don't collect them there and then (and i can assure you, you WON'T be able to collect them all): a return trip will leave you dissappointed as they won't be there if you miss them first time around. 

One concern regarding the game are the followers. Now these fellows I'd say are very important when it comes to conquering the game at harder levels: the enemy will give you no quarter. Goblins swarm you, whilst Orcs are powerful and well armoured (never fight them in tight spaces unless you fight like Geralt of Rivia), there is a plethora of other enemies that'll make securing your Kingdom even harder. Followers seem to be the way forward, but issues arise when you're having to fight in Caves or anywhere that isn't flat: they get stuck and you're left to fight alone (and die alone). 

Aside from these aspects I think this is a good game overall, the combination of constructing a town combined with exploration and fighting/conquering new grounds to help expand create a solid foundation that could well be expanded into something more in future. The game is not easy much to its benefit and it doesn't always give you warning as to what to expect in each area so you need to be cautious and not barrell through everything. Overall its good, but still has issues that need to be addressed.

40349009.review:
Great game! The best application of the platformer genre I've played in years.  

It plays as simply and intuitively as an SNES classic, but with more complexity and personality than most modern AAA titles, an incredible world that manages to feel gigantic in scope while pocket sized in accessibility.  It's is masterpeice of 2D world building. 

The exploration and area liberation system is extremely rewarding and like the rest of the gameplay it's complex but very intuitive, simplicity is a strength for Regions of Ruin where it never feels like design decisions where made out of comprimise and every peice of gameplay fits together just right to compliment the rest.

Regions of Ruin's world feels expansive and alive with interesting NPCs and it's own history to absorb. You get a real feel for how this world works simply by experiencing the environments and reading single sentence quests/responses.

Combat, Stealth, strategy, resource management, RPG, some troop management, a bit of town building and even some great rune puzzling that requires observation and learning about the world (I chose to use a pencil and paper to record rune patterns I saw and it made me SSOOO happy as an old school gamer) all well integrated without complicated sub-menus to learn and sort through. 

All that plus lots of sweet loot to find as well as great atmosphere and sound make Regions of Ruin a real easy recomendation.

40242468.review:
A charming and addictive game that could use some work in resource and difficulty balancing, as well as a tool tip system.

I saw this game come up on my Facebook feed (a Humble Games ad) and thought, wow that looks cool. The price made it 'risk worthy' so I went in blind.

The first few hours were a combination of addictive and confusing. There is not much in the way of instruction or help in the game, and dealing with some of the game mechanics can be daunting at first. Some things are not labelled well or at all. Even after finishing it, some questions linger.

It was however, very fun and satisfying. I played with the keyboard and definitely recommend customizing the layout. I used the mouse when dealing with menus and the main world map, and that turned out to be a good combination of controls.

The gameplay is simple at its core. Explore, hack, slash, loot. Collect workers to gather resources and build your town. As you explore, side quests become available, and an overarching story begins to tie locations together. Some clues found at certain locations can be used at others, so it is a good idea to keep your eyes open. I ended up using the screen cap feature on OSX quite a bit to 'take pictures' of ancient writings in case I needed them later.

There is a huge variety of weapons, armor and enchantments. It is a lot of fun discovering a new enchantment and seeing how you can use it to mow down your enemies. I became a throwing axe sniper, picking off enemies before they even knew I was there. The action looks, feels and sounds very satisfying. Throwing an axe through a row of enemies that is charging you is a joy.

As the game progresses, the enemies will force you to learn new strategies and fighting styles. For the first 30% of the game I ignored my shield entirely, but it became much more important in order to defeat foes later on.

Character progression is a mixed bag. It is a lot of fun to make a level and get a new skill. You can choose from a range of melee, axe, shield or power hitting skills. You also get one (1!) attribute point, which seems kind of anemic when I can regularly find weapons and armor that add attribute points in multiples of 10. I'm not sure if base values are more important than values added by equipment, as that isn't made clear.

With all its charm and early progression, it is very addictive at the beginning. Eventually, however, there is some flaws that make themselves evident. 

Resources seem to be strewn about in a very unblanced way. You will definitely be desperate for some, while drowning in others. There is eventually a market that helps solve that problem, but at great expense.

Selling items is a very time intensive process because there is only a few places on the entire map that will buy them, and they have very little gold to spend. You will find yourself trading item for item moreso, and these dwarves are not generous with their prices! It's not really a problem early on, but as the game progresses you will be running out of places to keep all the items you collect but want to sell. The buyers resupply gold every time you visit their map location but it could mean a lot of travelling in order to sell your items, which is tedious.

The difficulty level does seem to follow a particular path through exploration, and if you head too early into an area, you will get smashed. It is not a problem as saves are free and auto save is frequent. However, eventually your character will be so powerful, not much will challenge him. I cleared the whole map before visiting the final boss and I killed him with axes from a distance. He never even knew I was there. Obviously I was overpowered for that particular battle.

All in all, this game is very well done, but while it is addictive and challenging at the beginning, the wheels fall off as it nears the end and it becomes a cakewalk. Perhaps some auto difficulty scaling and some better enemy AI could keep it challenging?

Overall I recommend it because I enjoyed it immensely from start to finish, even with its flaws. I would love to see more of this world.

Wait, C) wait until he gets close enough and smash him, then while he's realing take 2 steps away and wait until he gets close enough and repeat the process until he's dead.... not very fun. 

Graphics: 5

Controls: 5
I wanted to play on a controller at first but without remapping everything its just a mess. M&K is aight but again it's no Dead Cells. Very basic and choppy feeling. 

In the end the game feels more like a proof of concept more so than a polished and shiny new product, but with a 12$ price tag you can still get your monies worth out of it if nothing else to just get a feel for the concept.

40073038.review:
Found this game intensely satisfying/addicting for the first 5-7 hours...!

Love the pixel graphics.  Gameplay is solid -- smashing boxes and monsters with your weapon of choice is great.  The leveling system is pretty neat.  Wish it had a better soundtrack, though the current one is not bad (any 8-bit, chiptune, or synth would've done! hotline miami, hyperlight drifter, and kingdom all have enviable soundtracks for this kind of game).  The game does manage to capture a bit of that 'kingdom' feel, and for a few hours it scratches the itch of those who have been asking: "Why isn't there a pixel-graphic rpg where I explore a big world while building a base and fighting monsters?"

Sadly, while it has a ton of great features and little side-quests/mini games, it all falls short after that first 5-7 hours.  Gameplay becomes repetitive as hell.  The town building system reveals itself to be fairly shallow, linear, and somewhat pointless.  (Yes, your upgraded buildings serve their respective function better, but for the most part they feel pointless.  E.g. an upgraded blacksmith lets you make better weapons and armor, but by the time you get it upgraded you've probably found better gear.)  Every goblin/kobold/orc camp starts to look the same.  The game's sub-systems start to lose their edge; it matters less that a new bounty or a new companion is available because after an hour or two you know exactly how it's all going to work out.

Offhand, I'm not sure what could've made this game principally better.  The possible addition of a storyline to give the game some cohesion after you've explored 1/3rd of the map?  More activities and ways to develop your town?  Perhaps greater quest diversity; every quest or map node that didn't result in dwarves sending me to kill more of the same monster was a treat.  I guess I expected a richer world -- there are so many possible map nodes that not every one of them can hold some interesting little thing, but after a while one tends to know exactly what's going to happen in  this game.  I feel terrible because on so many levels this game should work, but all of the elements end up being less than the sum of their parts.

40054167.review:
Total time to 100% completion: 14 hours.

Wow. Just wow.

I'm a huge 8 bit RPG fan, and this game really hit the nail on the head for me.

[SPOILER ALERT]


Pros:
-Immersive storyline(s) (more subplots than just the main dwarf vs. goblin story)
-Beautiful soundtrack
-Diverse weaponry, armor, jewelry, landscapes, enemies, NPCs, dialogue, quests
-Balanced leveling
-Cool little puzzles
-Having workers gather resources for you was an awesome feature
-Always working toward something
-Rewarding rewards (i.e. you always had to do something challenging to get the best gear, resources, etc)
-Cheaply priced for what you get
-Easy to binge for hours of playing, losing track of time

Cons:
-Platforming was very, very glitchy at times
-AI Companions pathfinding needs work, as they were kind of falling all over the place. They are also way too overpowered early-game.
-No real late-game village building/upgrading. I had my village fully built and upgraded (minus the runeforge) around halfway through the game. It would be cool to see more late-game features and upgrades.
-Over-powered legendary items; as soon as I got the Heart of the Inferno, I was one/two shotting every enemy.
-Anti-climatic final boss: goes hand in hand with overpowered legendary items, very easy boss, no sense of danger at all
-Too short!

All in all, worth it for the price. Judging by the ending credits message, it seems like there's a sequel set up. Vox Games, you've come out of nowhere with a masterpiece. I will buy every game you create until you stop creating games. This was just too good.

I have finished the game with less than 1/3 of the map explored. I just rushed it and had no problems with the last boss. My workers stayed home most of the time because I had like 30 of them and they mined everything so fast I could not keep up with finding new places. I did not even look at the stats of items because I made my own, which were leagues better and could be customized by me.

Ultimately, this is just not challenging, samey and boring.

Also, the game also does not know if it wants you to use keyboard with both hands (fighting) or keyboard+mouse (town).

39989303.review:
A delightful RPG platformer with some light city building as a leveling mechanism.

The majority of the game is played by choosing a location on a map, killing the baddies there, then choosing your home base on the map so you can heal, sell buy and forge loot, and level up both yourself and your cities buildings.

The fighting element is mostly casually paced, not frantic. Kiting is a valid and important strategy. There is alot of loot. Each short map will drop anywhere from 5 to 10+ pieces of loot of varying quality. You can quick attack, strong attack, throw axes, shield, dash, jump, and unlock special abilities. All of which use a stamina bar to prevent you from spamming attacks.

The skill tree is more about play style than it is raw power.  For increasing power there is both a "find all the pages of a book and unlock buff" element and a forge element that allows you to buff your equipment.

City management is a meta game. You harvest resources from area's you've cleared of enemies, then use those resources to upgrade your city. Upgrading the forge for example will allow you to forge new types of ore blocks, upgrading the tavern gives you more daily income. There are roughly 8 buildings to build, and you will end up building all of them, city management is not strategic beyond priortizing your play style.

If you enjoy pixel graphics, this game is beautiful. The music and sounds are well done too but don't add much. 

Over all great game. Small learning curve leads to a satisfying RPG platforming experience.

39961473.review:
This game is a mix of a platformer, an RPG, and sort of a village-builder/ressource-manager light with puzzle elements. You play a dwarven hero who is tasked with building a village, recruiting other dwarves (as workers or combat allies), and exploring the world until you find a way back to the dwarven kingdom underground. Cleared regions hold a finite amount of ressources, which your workers can gather in real time.

Your hero can mix and match abilities from four combat trees: standard attacks/axe throwing/shield/power attacks and there are three stats to distribute points to. Strength=Melee, Dexterity=Ranged, Constitution=Health. Simple.

You can find or forge all sorts of equipment, and sell/dismantle what you don't need. Your village can consist up to about ten different buildings such as: smithy, tavern, trading post, campfire, etc. All of these can be upgraded multiple times, provided you have enough ressources.

Said ressources consist of food, wood, fur, wool, stone, coal and several metals.

All in all I found this a nice little game, which I played for hours on each go. As I'm approaching the end I find the game worth its money. It was a quite interesting and refreshing experience, such as often only indie games can provide.

39952995.review:
[h1]A 2D platformer RPG with a base to build up and a continent to explore makes this an easy recommendation for the price-point it sits at, if light and thin in general.[/h1]

[b][i][u]POSITIVES[/u][/i][/b]
[list]
 [*]+ Consistent pixel-style art and feel in 2D all throughout makes this a "comfy" game to look at. Combine this with a significant basis in 2D platforming and you have something inherently fun to play.

 [*]+ A solid RPG layered in between a location-based exploration overmap, with a base building mechanic in between that complete with resource mechanics and tiering makes this a meal for both number crunchers and base builders alike. Its always worth exploring, for both personal gear and resources. Its always worth progressing through the map, for legendary gear locked behind world-spanning puzzles and similar.

 [*]+ *Multiple* quests and other such puzzles that run across the land as well as over time as you progress gives you something to do as you go through each location.
[/list]

======

[b][i][u]NEGATIVES[/u][/i][/b]
[list]
 [*]- Pixel-style art direction and execution makes this game not stand out as much unlike previous generations' offerings, which does not help it stand out. Upon first glance, it, by its very design, looks like a melee combat platform RPG.

 [*]- As solid as its mechanics interplay between character RPG, base building, resource gathering, and exploration, one can end up in a situation where the scaling is haphazardly sharp. You can end up being very overpowered with a full team of 10 highly powerful companions to go with enemies that can just as easily severely wound you through your tough overpowered armor for no evident reason, whist in most other situations, attacks can just as much No-Sell.

 [*]- Said haphazard scaling also applies to the resource collection and base building, wherein one can pretty much have everything after 10-15 hours and have little more to progress on that front. Beyond this point, resources are collected just to feed personally crafted gear, which can have weird balance ranges, leading you to have either vastly underpowered, or vastly overpowered gear.

 [*]- Exploration loop can easily become samey after similar number of hours, with locations becoming samey to one another. This does not help the puzzle mechanics as well, as it is difficult to find locations where the solution or clues to one puzzle can be across the map full of locations, with little to no indications where which is what and where. Combine this with a journal system that is decisively several generations ago obsolete (anyone remember Morrowind's journal? yeah...) makes it difficult to track quests you're on, puzzles you're trying to solve, and the like.
[/list]

39948804.review:
On the surface is a pretty simple game. It's a side scroller ARPG where you essentially kill all the enemies and loot the rewards and then repeat the process probably a hundred or more so times. It sounds tedious, but there was always something that intrigued me to continue. 

Perhaps it was the gathering resources to upgrade my settlement. Perhaps it was the very thoughtful amount of book pages to collect that not only serve as lore for the game but also give good bonuses as well. Perhaps it was solving all the runes and see what type of unique item I got. Or maybe it was something just as simple as playing an idle game within the game. Whatever it was it got me addicted, I beat the game in 2 whole sittings. 

13 hours is pretty standard I'd say. Didn't complete everything. Personally though I don't know if I want to.
 As much as I enjoyed the inital playthrough of the game, by the time you beat it, there's not much else you'd want to achieve. I could clear out all the Runes and get purple tiered adamantite armor to match my flame sword. I could max out the remaining 2-3 buildings in my settlement. But again I don't see much point to. It was when you were playing through and realized that there was a much broader scope of enemies to fight. That you needed to craft better weapons, armor and shields. To do that you needed to upgrade your town. The game got harder the further away you got from your settlment. Heck it took me 10 hours before I can finally rob the dwarf for his book page. But once you beat it, what else can you do? By that point you are already at God-level. There's not much else to achieve past that point. I feel like a more dedicated post-game is something this game needs. I am not saying that don't feel like I deserve my  accomplishments or the game didn't give me a challenge. The final boss took me many tries before I could finally beat him. But unless I am wrong, I don't think anyone can get much tougher than that. 

This isn't to scare away anyone from buying this game. Trust there's loads to do to keep you pre-occupied. This game definitely had a lot of love and care put into it. I ate up whatever new thing it threw at me. Also, despite beating the game I still haven't unlocked a single achievement.

Edit: I did go back just out of sheer curiosity of review. And I was right, there really isn't a post game outside of the final boss.

39945287.review:
写在前面。
这是一款横版的角色扮演游戏，游戏风格很像像素海盗，同时加入了像骑马与砍杀的建造系统，以及放逐之城的资源采集，看着是roguelike游戏其实并不是。

下面给一下游戏的一个发展思路：
1.开局请选择困难模式，一是在这模式下，宝箱掉落稀有装备的数量更多，二是难度是可以在设置下往下面调的（不可逆）。
困难模式下会掉落大量的项链和戒指以及稀有装备，它们的价值是远远超过护甲和武器装备的，是前期金钱的重要来源，打开宝箱时可以F5/F8（S/L）来刷装备，游戏装备分为（橙>绿>蓝>白）,金色宝箱时请务必刷出至少一个的绿装。

2.做完新手教学后，你会到一片新土地上发展，此时你要做的第一件事是建旅馆，旅馆可以通过消耗有效时间获得金钱，也可以接委托和雇佣雇佣兵。扫完周围几个据点后，凑钱购买一个弓箭手，由于弓箭手的攻击力在初期的数值比玩家和怪物高太多所以你只要在前面举盾就好了。以后就可以有钱就买弩手（2000多一个的那种）

3.在一个工人的指引下你会找到一个铁匠，前期的装备耐久低，比较必要

4.大地图的左下角有让工人出去开发资源的锤子按钮，打完周围第一个据点就可以开启。

5.打不过时请不要勉强，可以随时切地图离开的

6.关于加点：（力量/敏捷/体质）有这三种，请随便加，因为后期装备的影响远远大于你的等级上的点数影响。技能的话，个人而言，蓄力攻击没什么用，主要还是依靠平A和冲刺绕后的打法，远程可以点一点作为初期的偷鸡打法，后面伤害太低了。

7.中后期的收入来源主要是接赏金任务，所以请一直把旅馆的优先级放到最高，任务完成后找旅馆老板拿钱好了。

8.猎杀赏金对象时请注意，如果碰到高难度的魔法类的boss，请你自己把它给打死，或者放弃，它的随便一击都是穿透攻击的情况下你的队伍会死很多人。

9.赏金类boss是有偷鸡打法的，具体如下：（1）.你的成员远程兵居多，全员设置为等待指令状态。（2）走到boss跟前勾引往回走，走到地图边界，boss走过来时会一直会被你的远程兵揍，但是不还手（3）因为boss只想打你，所以你跟它绕就好了

10.由于赏金任务来钱特别快，攒到一定程度后，先把所有装备换成价值1w以上，再买3w以上的戒指和项链，你的战力就差不多到后期了，此时你的雇佣兵已经打不动高级敌人了，你可以自己带上血瓶自己刷了。

11.很多系统还有很多的改进，例如装备打造系统就是个笑话，图书馆的掉落收集奖励少，而且意义不明

12.写到这吧，这游戏后期真特么无聊。

39938674.review:
Fantastic title, well worth the price! They've nailed the gameplay mechanics of killing and looting and repeating. There was obviously some inspiration from Skyrim with the intro music and a subtlety reminiscent of Norse mythology. The combat is enjoyable if not diverse, the loot and leveling system are solid. The lore hidden in the game is immersive and interesting as well as the interconnecting side stories not dissimilar to a Bethesda title.

There are just a few minor issues listed as follows:
- Storage is arbitrarily limited which makes sense buuut
- You can only build one of any given structure
- Companions are fairly useless, they don't level as the game gets more difficult
- Stealth could use some love; quite buggy
- Axe throwing is easily exploited by standing just outside of small AI range

Some "it-would-be-cool-if's":
- Pets
- Customizeable house with armor stands and weapon racks
- Useable bow like the AI have
- Some sort of magic system (also like the AI)
- Beefier companions that get more expensive
- More difficult/rewarding contracts from the tavern (maxes at 2k gold with super easy bosses)


But yeah. Good game, definitely recommend.

From the outside looking in, Regions of Ruin seemed to be breaking the mold of your typical side-scrolling RPG. Unfortunately, upon further review, the game lacks character, mechanical flow and ability to contain your attention for more than ten minutes.

The game is fun for that first 15 or so minutes but then after that... it's already stale. It already lost it's uniqueness, and sadly the reviews do not live up to their hype.

39909760.review:
Regions of Ruin is a fun game for the asking price.  I disagree with many of the similarities drawn to other games as Regions of Ruin does a good job of being unique.  It's definitely -not- focused on being a kingdom simulator and instead is very heavily focused on the 2D hack and slash action aspect.

+ RoR has a very creative way of handling exploration in a 2D setting.  The world map is a nice idea.
+ Lore.  There's plenty of goodies left scattered around like scattered journals and dwarven survivors to tell a story of this ruined world.
+ The action aspect is simple but well done.  The rock-paper-scissors formula of force attack beats block beats quick attack beats force attack is satisfying to use against the enemy and avoid falling victim to.
+ You can recruit your very own throng of dwarves from the tavern who will faithfully attempt to follow you around and murder things.
= The hired dwarves will end up doing most of the work and turn maps into massive smash and grabs.
= Stealth is an interesting idea but is mostly useless besides the early levels introducing it before you get an army.  The free thrown axe critical is what stealth boils down to later.
= Difficulty spikes.  You will grow complacent fighting green goblins and kobolds.  But when the orcs, trolls, or the red variants are encountered, life immediately becomes much harder.
= Stats and skills exist.  Some of them offer a drastic change in playstyle, others are a small boost only selected to unlock better things.  
- The dwarven AI can't pathfind at all like the other AI.  They will fall down a hole with a ladder and just run into the wall instead of using the ladder
- The city simulator aspect of this game is extremely weak.  It doesn't change how it behaves as it grows.  Only the workers move around and are the most alive part of the city.  The rest are just stationary upgrades to unlock another quest or more stuff for the player.

39880342.review:
[h1]TL:DR:[/h1]
The game is fun, settlement building adds an extra layer of purpose, and overall the game feels very polished.  Sound is good, graphics are exactly what the pictures show, and the story is interesting.  Would recommend to fans of the genre and newbies who want to try something different.

[h1]First Impression Gameplay:[/h1]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=44-8Ic6rJrY&feature=youtu.be

[h1]Regular Review[/h1]
While I don't often play side scrolling retro-looking adventure type games, I did enjoy my time with Regions of Ruin.  The story is interesting, the game-play is smooth and fun, and I also enjoy the settlement building.  I believe that the added responsibility of collecting resources to build settlement buildings adds an extra layer of purpose to these games, other than just go here, kill that.

Apart from game play, the music is good and catchy and the sound effects work well.  Not sure what to say about the graphics, other than they are the basic retro-pixel style that you see a lot in steam indie games nowadays.  Look at the store page screenshots, that's what you'll get in the visual department.

The story and quests feel meaningful, as you are trying to rebuild a Dwarven community.  NPS's give you quests which are not just "go here and do that", but impact how your settlement grows and the resources you can gather.  Once you recruit some workers, you can send them off to collect resources from cleared areas you've already explored.  I enjoy that mechanic, as it adds and extra layer of usefulness to previously cleared areas.

Combat can be tricky and I still haven't fully gotten the hang of it.  The control scheme feels a bit off, but again I don't usually play these types of games.  Keys can be remapped, so it's not really an issue.

Overall, the game is fun and enjoyable, and I think it is priced fairly at $10.  Even if the game goes off sale to the regular price of $12, I'd recommend picking it up for fans of the genre.

39659795.review:
So... where to start? Well, it's a genuinely solid little game that I recommend, there's that. 

If you want details? well, okay, we can do that. What do I usually talk about in a big review... graphics I guess? It's got a nice retro style to the game, it looks like a throwback to the days of the old NES, but crucially it doesn't have that entire 'I made the graphics all pixelly so they look old and now it's impossible to tell what anything is' problem some games that try to look retro have. Full marks there.

The gameplay is solid as well, the platforming sections are all challenging without being too easy or too difficult and that's a genuinely hard balance to achieve. It can get hectic when enemies are shooting you off tiny little ledges, but the individual areas aren't ever massive enough that this becomes a problem or frustrating or outright makes it impossible to progress. I'll mention the skill trees as well, while we are talking about gameplay - they are, like the rest of the game, very solid. Stealth feels a little weak, but then again I didn't spec for it so I have no idea how it plays out in the late game - it could become incredibly overpowered for all I know. I never used the ranged tree either, I sort of wandered between the defence tree and the basic melee tree, and it worked. It worked very, very well and that's another thing this game has going for it, since a lot of the time when a skill tree is there you need to fully dedicate yourself to it or you gimp your character. Bonus points for this not happening.

Combat. You can block, use power attacks to break through enemies who are trying to block, and you have normal melee attacks. The various weapons are different enough and the skills change things up enough that this makes combat fun and it stays fun right to the end of that game. I went with a build focused on super rapid but weak melee strikes and a weapon with a massively high crit rating. I was a blender until I ran into enemies who had tower shields, when things suddenly became much trickier. Good fun all around.

The world. Okay, this is the bit I loved most, and this is where the game shines. There are at my count ...uh... yeah, not actually gonna count all the locations, because as it happens there are a LOT of them, and all of them are unique. Rather than just using a generic random terrain generator to make locations the guy developing the game built them all by hand, and I suspect he play tested them all personally as well. Every location is different and it makes the world feel really alive and gives you a reason to explore because you'll find a new quest or item or challenging little encounter, and they are all really nicely laid out.

Had to come back and add this bit in, because I totally forgot about it, but you get to build your own settlement and give all the dwarven refugee's you find and captives you rescue a home. They go out to gather resources from areas you clear and you can use those to improve the settlement and so on and so on. You go from using a rusty sword and a dead rat as a shield (one of those might be a slight exaggeration) to being able to forge and enchant your own Adamantine weapons and armour, and you can recruit a variety of little beardy followers to go merrily charging into combat with you. Up to ten of them in fact. If the Skeleton Butler ever makes it in, you can thank me in the comments below.

What else? The developer. Okay, I don't usually put this bit in a review, but seriously. I found a bug with a quest, posted it on the Steam forums and not only did I get a personal apology from the guy but the bug was squashed four days later in the weekly hotfix.

Yeah.

Weekly.

I'm not kidding. If you happen to find a bug you can basically watch it get fixed in realtime right now. That's insane.


Do I have any issues with the game at all? well, I'm not completely sure, but I think the guy might have made his own dwarven rune language and if I'd learned to translate the messages I found I would have gotten a fair bit of extra stuff in the form of treasures and secrets. That's it. The closest thing to a problem with the game was 'the developer might have invented a dwarven language and I couldn't be arsed to translate it'.

If I'd have typed this review up a week or so earlier then I'd have a bit here complaining about how the quest system doesn't tell you where you got quests from or where you need to go, and with the journal being a bit vague it made finishing quests quite hard, but guess what was added in a hotfix this week?



Lastly, I'll say that I won this game for free on a stream by my favourite Youtuber, Nookrium. if you love games like this or strategy type stuff in general, especially if it's indie then get you to Youtube and go take a look at his channel.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCwX8RD5ivBjTm1QHIv7fm_Q
